title: Project Closure
description: Formal project closure—acceptance, contracts, lessons learned, resources, and transition to operations.
objectives: Understand closure as FORMAL process (not just 'work is done')
Identify 7 closure activities: acceptance, contracts, lessons, resources, archive, transfer, celebrate
Apply contract closeout rules for fixed-price vs cost-reimbursable
Recognize that ALL projects need closure—even cancelled ones

screens.headline: Grand Opening Success! Restaurant Packed. 4.5 Stars. Carlos: 'Project Done!' But Is It Really Closed?

dialogue.text: Project's done! Great work everyone—back to your regular jobs!

counterpoint.text: Not so fast. The grand opening happened, but the PROJECT isn't closed. Formal closure is still needed.

screens.learningHook: When is a project truly closed? Is work completion enough, or are formal steps required?

screens.title: Formal Closure Activities
screens.instructions: Identify closure activities, apply contract closeout, and understand early termination.

scenarios.title: Stage 1: What's Part of Formal Closure?

feedback.correct: Perfect! 7 closure activities: Acceptance, Contracts, Lessons, Resources, Archive, Transfer, Celebrate.
feedback.incorrect: Closure = ending THIS project. Not starting the next one. Include all formalization activities.

questions.question: What should Alex do with the $5K?

options.text: Review contract: Fixed-price = Pay $5K. Cost-reimbursable = Reclaim savings.

feedback.correct: Contract terms determine closeout. Fixed-price = pay agreed price. Cost-reimbursable = pay actual costs.
feedback.incorrect: Contract type matters! Fixed-price: contractor bears risk, gets full price. Cost-reimbursable: buyer pays actual costs.

questions.question: Does a cancelled project need formal closure?

options.text: YES—Document why, close contracts, release team, capture lessons, archive docs
NO—Closure is only for completed projects
Partial—Close contracts only, skip lessons learned
Wait 6 months to see if project restarts

feedback.correct: ALL projects require formal closure—even cancelled ones. Cancelled projects have the MOST valuable lessons.
feedback.incorrect: Cancelled projects need closure: close contracts, release resources, capture why it failed. Don't waste the learning.

content.reality: Work complete ≠ Project closed. Formal process needed.

activities.name: Resource Release
activities.detail: Team formally released to next work

fixedPrice.closeout: Pay full contract price if work complete

costReimbursable.terms: Reimburse ACTUAL COSTS up to NTE
costReimbursable.closeout: Pay actual costs, reclaim unused budget

content.insight: Failed projects have the MOST valuable lessons learned.

correct.text: Closure is FORMAL process. Skipping it creates liability (contracts), wastes learning (lessons), strands resources (team).
I thought cancelled = just stop work. But we must close contracts, release team, capture lessons, archive docs. Cancelled projects need closure too.

screens.title: Software Project Closure
screens.context: Software delivered, Product Owner accepted. Still need: release 5 developers, terminate $10K/month hosting contract, schedule lessons learned, archive docs.

questions.question: Which activities are required for formal closure?

screens.title: Project Closure Mastery
screens.summary: Formal closure is required for ALL projects—completed, cancelled, or suspended. It includes acceptance, contracts, lessons, resources, archive, transfer, and celebration.
takeaways: Work complete ≠ Project closed. Formal process needed.
7 activities: Acceptance, Contracts, Lessons, Resources, Archive, Transfer, Celebrate
ALL projects need closure—even cancelled ones
Contract closeout honors contract terms (fixed-price vs cost-reimbursable)
Cancelled projects have the most valuable lessons
Transition to operations enables benefits realization

characterClosing.text: I thought grand opening = project done. But Alex showed me: get Elena's signature, close Javier's contract, capture lessons, release team, archive docs, transfer to operations, celebrate. Now Riverside Plaza is formally closed.
